<extra_id_1>1

Cognitive biases are systematic errors in thinking that occur when people are processing and interpreting information in the world around them and making decisions. These biases can lead to irrational judgments and poor choices because they cause us to filter data through our own personal experiences, beliefs, emotions, and values rather than relying solely on objective facts. There are many different types of cognitive biases, including confirmation bias (the tendency to favor information that supports preexisting views), anchoring bias (reliance on initial pieces of data), and availability heuristic (judging frequency by how easily examples come to mind).
